refnamediv.refpurpose: cast Produces a result array with the same dimensions, attributes, and cells as a source arrayâ€”but with other differences, which can include different names for its dimensions or attributes, different nulls-allowed status for an attribute, and different datatypes for its dimensions.

refsect1.title: Summary
refsect1.para: The cast operator has three primary uses:

listitem.para: To change names of attributes or dimensions
To change a nulls-disallowed attribute to a nulls-allowed attribute

refsect1.para: A single cast invocation can be used to make all of these changes at once. The input array and template arrays should have the same numbers and types of attributes.
The cells of the result array have the same attribute values as the corresponding cells of the source array.
You can use the cast operator in the FROM clause of an AQL SELECT statement, as a stand-alone operator in a AFL statement, or as an operand within other SciDB operators.

informalexample.para: This example shows the schema of an array, combines the recast and store operators to change some characteristics of the array, and shows the schema of the new array.

step.para:
Show the schema of an existing array:--afl store(build(<event:string>[i=0:*,12,0],'["dash","dash","steeplechase","marathon","marathon", "marathon"]',true),event); --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(build(<year:int64>[i=0:*,12,0],'[1996,2000,2000,1996,2000,2008]',true),year); --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(build(<person:string>[i=0:*,12,0],'["Bailey","Greene","Kosgei","Thugwane","Abera", "Wanjiru"]',true),person); --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(build(<country:string>[i=0:*,12,0],'["Canada","USA","Kenya","USA","Ethiopia", "Kenya"]',true),country); --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(build(<time:double>[i=0:*,12,0],'[9.84,9.87,503.17,7956,7811,7596]',true),time); --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(join(event,join(year,(join(person,join(country,time))))),winnersFewFlat); --show-query=no --show-output=no
--afl create array champions <person:string,country:string,time:double, event:string> [year=1996:2008,1,0]; --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(redimension(winnersFewFlat,champions),champions); --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl store(project(champions,time),winningTime); --show-query=no --show-output=no --schema winningTime
Use the cast operator to produce a result array similar to the existing array, but with these changes:

listitem.para: The attribute in the new array allows null values.
The attribute in the new array is called "time_in_seconds."

step.para: In this example, the cast operator appears as an operand of the store operator, yielding a named array "winningTimeRecast":--afl store ( cast ( winningTime, <time_in_seconds:double null> [year=1996:2008,1,0] ), winningTimeRecast ); --output-format=dcsv
Show the schema of the new array:--schema winningTimeRecast
